winmail_page.how_to_intro:
If you've ever received an email with a mysterious attachment called "winmail.dat", you're not alone. This file is created by Microsoft Outlook when it sends emails using a proprietary format called TNEF (Transport Neutral Encapsulation Format). Non-Outlook email clients like Gmail, Apple Mail, and Thunderbird can't decode this format, leaving you with an unopenable attachment.

Our winmail.dat viewer extracts the original email content and attachments right in your browser. The file is parsed locally using our custom-built TNEF decoder — nothing is uploaded to any server, so your email content stays completely private.

how_to_steps.title: Select Your winmail.dat File
how_to_steps.description: Drag and drop your winmail.dat file onto the upload area, or click to browse and select it from your device. Only one file is processed at a time.

how_to_steps.title: View Email Content
how_to_steps.description: The tool automatically parses the file and displays the email subject, sender information, and message body. If the email contains HTML formatting, you can toggle between plain text and HTML views.

how_to_steps.title: Download Attachments
how_to_steps.description: All attachments embedded in the winmail.dat file are listed with their file names, sizes, and types. Download each file individually, or use the "Download All as ZIP" button to get everything in a single archive.

winmail_page.how_to_outro: The parsing process is nearly instant for typical winmail.dat files. Since all processing happens locally in your browser using our custom TNEF parser, your email data — including any sensitive attachments — never leaves your device.

faq.question: What is a winmail.dat file?
faq.answer: A winmail.dat file is created by Microsoft Outlook when it sends emails using TNEF (Transport Neutral Encapsulation Format). This format bundles the email body, formatting, and attachments into a single binary file. Email clients other than Outlook can't decode this format, so they display it as a generic "winmail.dat" attachment.

faq.question: Is it safe to open winmail.dat files with this tool?
faq.answer: Yes, completely safe. This tool parses the file entirely in your browser — no data is sent to any server. If the file contains HTML email content, it is sanitized with DOMPurify and displayed in a sandboxed iframe to prevent any potential security risks.

faq.question: Why do I keep receiving winmail.dat files?
faq.answer: You receive winmail.dat files when someone sends you an email from Microsoft Outlook configured to use Rich Text Format (RTF). The TNEF encoding wraps the email content and attachments into a single file that non-Outlook clients can't read. You can ask the sender to switch to HTML or Plain Text format in their Outlook settings.

faq.question: Can I extract attachments from winmail.dat?
faq.answer: Yes! This tool extracts all embedded attachments from the winmail.dat file. You'll see each attachment listed with its original file name and size. You can download them individually or all at once as a ZIP archive.

faq.question: What types of content can be inside a winmail.dat file?
faq.answer: A winmail.dat file can contain the email subject, sender and recipient information, the email body (in plain text and/or HTML format), and any file attachments. Common attachments include documents (PDF, Word, Excel), images, and other files that were sent with the original email.

faq.question: How can I prevent sending winmail.dat files?
faq.answer: If you use Microsoft Outlook, go to File > Options > Mail, and under "Compose messages in this format", select "HTML" or "Plain Text" instead of "Rich Text". You can also change the format for individual contacts by editing their contact card and selecting "Internet Format: Send Plain Text Only".

faq.question: Does this tool work on mobile devices?
faq.answer: Yes! The tool works on any device with a modern web browser, including smartphones and tablets. Simply open the page, select your winmail.dat file, and the tool will parse and display the contents.

webp_page.how_to_title: How to Convert WebP to JPG or PNG
webp_page.how_to_intro:
WebP is a modern image format developed by Google that offers superior compression compared to traditional formats like JPG and PNG. While WebP files are significantly smaller in size, they aren't universally supported by all applications and platforms. If you've downloaded a WebP image from the web and can't open it in your image editor, or need to share it with someone whose device doesn't support WebP, this tool makes conversion quick and easy.

Our WebP converter runs entirely in your browser using the HTML5 Canvas API. This means your images are never uploaded to any server — they stay on your device throughout the entire conversion process.

how_to_steps.title: Select Your Files
how_to_steps.description: Drag and drop your WebP files onto the upload area, or click to browse and select files from your device. You can convert multiple files at once — there's no limit on the number of files.

how_to_steps.title: Choose Your Output Format
how_to_steps.description: Select either JPG or PNG as your output format. JPG is best for photographs and complex images where a smaller file size is preferred. PNG is ideal for images that require transparency or sharp edges, such as logos, screenshots, and graphics.

how_to_steps.title: Adjust Quality (JPG only)
how_to_steps.description: If you've selected JPG as the output format, you can adjust the quality slider from 0% to 100%. A quality of 90% offers an excellent balance between file size and visual quality. Lower values produce smaller files but with some loss of detail.

how_to_steps.title: Download Your Converted Files
how_to_steps.description: Once the conversion is complete, you can download each file individually or use the "Download All as ZIP" button to get all converted files in a single ZIP archive.

webp_page.how_to_outro: The conversion process is instant for most files. Since everything runs locally in your browser, the speed depends only on your device's processing power, not on your internet connection.

faq.question: Is it safe to convert WebP files with this tool?
faq.answer: Yes, absolutely. This tool processes all files locally in your browser. Your images are never uploaded to any server. The conversion uses your browser's built-in Canvas API, so your files never leave your device.

faq.question: What is the difference between JPG and PNG output?
faq.answer: JPG (JPEG) uses lossy compression, which means file sizes are smaller but some image detail may be lost. It's best for photographs. PNG uses lossless compression, preserving all image details and supporting transparency. It's ideal for graphics, screenshots, and images with text.

faq.question: What quality setting should I use for JPG?
faq.answer: A quality of 90% provides an excellent balance between file size and visual quality. For web use, 80-85% is often sufficient. If you need the highest possible quality, use 100%, though the file size will be larger. For PNG output, quality settings don't apply since PNG is lossless.

faq.question: Is there a file size limit?
faq.answer: There is no strict file size limit since all processing happens in your browser. However, very large files (over 100MB) may cause your browser to slow down. For files over 500MB, your browser may run out of memory. We recommend converting large files one at a time.

faq.question: Can I convert multiple WebP files at once?
faq.answer: Yes! You can drag and drop multiple WebP files at once, or select multiple files from the file browser. All files will be converted with the same settings, and you can download them individually or as a single ZIP archive.

faq.question: Why can't I open WebP files on my computer?
faq.answer: WebP is a relatively new image format created by Google. While modern browsers and operating systems support it, some older applications and systems don't. Converting to JPG or PNG ensures your images can be opened by virtually any image viewer or editor.

faq.question: Does this tool work offline?
faq.answer: Once the page has loaded, the conversion tool works without an internet connection. However, you'll need an internet connection to initially load the page. Since all processing is done locally, the speed of conversion doesn't depend on your internet speed.

heic_page.how_to_title: How to Convert HEIC to JPG or PNG
heic_page.how_to_intro:
HEIC (High Efficiency Image Container) is the default photo format on iPhones and iPads running iOS 11 and later. While HEIC offers excellent image quality at roughly half the file size of JPG, it's not universally supported — Windows PCs, older Android devices, and many web applications and image editors still can't open HEIC files directly.

This tool converts your HEIC and HEIF photos to universally compatible JPG or PNG format right in your browser. The conversion uses WebAssembly-based decoding, so your photos are never uploaded to any server — they stay completely private on your device.

how_to_steps.title: Select Your HEIC Files
how_to_steps.description: Drag and drop your HEIC or HEIF files onto the upload area, or click to browse and select photos from your device. You can convert multiple files at once — perfect for batch-converting an entire photo library.

how_to_steps.title: Choose Your Output Format
how_to_steps.description: Select JPG (default) or PNG as your output format. JPG is recommended for photos since it produces smaller files while maintaining excellent visual quality. PNG is best when you need lossless quality or transparency.

how_to_steps.title: Adjust Quality (JPG only)
how_to_steps.description: When converting to JPG, use the quality slider to find the right balance between file size and image quality. The default setting of 90% preserves nearly all visual detail while keeping file sizes reasonable.

how_to_steps.title: Download Your Photos
how_to_steps.description: Once conversion is complete, download each photo individually or use the "Download All as ZIP" button to get all your converted photos in a single archive — great for transferring a batch of photos.

heic_page.how_to_outro: HEIC conversion typically takes 1-3 seconds per photo depending on resolution and your device's processing power. Since everything runs locally in your browser, no internet bandwidth is used during conversion.

faq.question: What is HEIC and why does my iPhone use it?
faq.answer: HEIC (High Efficiency Image Container) is a modern image format based on the HEVC (H.265) video codec. Apple adopted it as the default photo format on iPhones starting with iOS 11 because it produces files roughly 50% smaller than equivalent JPGs while maintaining the same or better image quality. This saves significant storage space on your device.

faq.question: Is it safe to convert HEIC files with this tool?
faq.answer: Yes, completely safe. This tool processes all files locally in your browser using WebAssembly technology. Your photos are never uploaded to any server — they remain entirely on your device throughout the conversion process. No one else can see or access your photos.

faq.question: Will I lose image quality when converting from HEIC to JPG?
faq.answer: Converting from HEIC to JPG involves re-encoding, so there is a minimal quality loss inherent to lossy compression. However, at the default quality setting of 90%, the difference is virtually imperceptible to the human eye. For truly lossless conversion, choose PNG as the output format.

faq.question: Can I convert HEIC photos from my iPhone on a Windows PC?
faq.answer: Yes! That's one of the primary use cases for this tool. Simply transfer your HEIC photos from your iPhone to your Windows PC (via USB, email, cloud storage, etc.), then use this tool to convert them to JPG or PNG. No additional software installation is needed — just your web browser.

faq.question: How do I stop my iPhone from taking photos in HEIC format?
faq.answer: You can change your iPhone's camera format by going to Settings > Camera > Formats, and selecting "Most Compatible" instead of "High Efficiency". This will make your iPhone save photos as JPG instead of HEIC. However, keep in mind that JPG files are roughly twice the size of HEIC files.

faq.question: Can I convert multiple HEIC files at once?
faq.answer: Yes! You can select or drag and drop multiple HEIC files simultaneously. All files will be converted with your chosen settings, and you can download them individually or as a single ZIP archive for convenience.

faq.question: What's the difference between HEIC and HEIF?
faq.answer: HEIF (High Efficiency Image Format) is the broader standard, while HEIC is specifically HEIF using HEVC compression. In practice, .heic and .heif files are essentially the same thing and this tool handles both formats identically.
